dt: {bc}a record of debit {dx_def}see {dxt|debit:2||1a}{/dx_def} and credit {dx_def}see {dxt|credit:1||2d}{/dx_def} entries to cover transactions involving a particular item or a particular person or concern

dt.t: She was asked to give an {wi}account{/wi} of her actions.

dt: {bc}a statement or exposition of reasons, causes, or motives
{bc}a formal business arrangement providing for regular dealings or services (such as banking, advertising, or store credit) and involving the establishment and maintenance of an account

dt.t: They are one of our most important {wi}accounts{/wi}.

{bc}an arrangement in which a person uses the Internet or email services of a particular company

dros.drp: give a good account of oneself

dt: {bc}to perform well especially in a competition or confrontation {bc}to acquit oneself well

dt.t: Though he has an aristocratic bearing, he could probably {wi}give a good account of himself{/wi} in a street fight.

dt: {bc}with the price charged to one's account

dt.t: The game was cancelled {it}on account of{/it} rain.
{it}On no account{/it} should the children be left alone at home.
I'm doing it {it}on my own account{/it}, not for anyone else.

et: Middle English {it}acounte, accompt{/it}, borrowed from Anglo-French {it}acunte, acounte{/it}, noun derivative of {it}acunter{/it} "to {et_link|account:2|account:2}"

a statement of transactions during a fiscal period and the resulting balance

dt: {bc}a garden or park walk bordered by trees or bushes
{bc}a grassed enclosure for bowling or skittles
{bc}a room or building housing a group of such lanes
{bc}the space on each side of a tennis doubles court between the sideline and the service sideline
{bc}an area in a baseball outfield between two outfielders when they are in normal positions

dt.t: hit a line drive into the {wi}alley{/wi}

dt: {bc}a thoroughfare through the middle of a block giving access to the rear of lots or buildings
{bc}an extensive region where destructive natural phenomena of a specified type (such as tornadoes) occur often or are likely to occur

dt.t: The most obvious tornado {wi}alley{/wi} extends from the plains of northwest Texas eastward into north Texas and then northward across Oklahoma, Kansas, and eastern Nebraska.

dt: {bc}suited to one's own tastes or abilities

dt.t: a job that's right {wi}up her alley{/wi}

et: Middle English, from Anglo-French {it}alee{/it}, from {it}aler{/it} to go
shortdef: a garden or park walk bordered by trees or bushes
a grassed enclosure for bowling or skittles
a hardwood lane for bowling; also : a room or building housing a group of such lanes

dt: {bc}any of a family (Formicidae) of colonial hymenopterous insects with a complex social organization and various castes performing special duties

shortdef: any of a family (Formicidae) of colonial hymenopterous insects with a complex social organization and various castes performing special duties

dt: {bc}the fleshy, usually rounded red, yellow, or green edible {d_link|pome|pome} fruit of a usually cultivated tree (genus {it}Malus{/it}) of the rose family
{bc}a fruit (such as a star apple) or other vegetative growth (such as an oak apple) suggestive of an apple

dt.t: his daughter is the {it}apple of his eye{/it}

et: Middle English {it}appel{/it}, from Old English {it}æppel{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}apful{/it} apple, Old Irish {it}ubull{/it}, Old Church Slavonic {it}ablŭko{/it}
shortdef: the fleshy, usually rounded red, yellow, or green edible pome fruit of a usually cultivated tree (genus Malus) of the rose family; also : an apple tree
a fruit (such as a star apple) or other vegetative growth (such as an oak apple) suggestive of an apple

dt: {bc}the rear part of the human body especially from the neck to the end of the spine
{bc}the body considered as the wearer of clothes

dt.t: They were left with nothing but the clothes on their {wi}backs{/wi}.

dt: {bc}the back considered as the seat of one's awareness of duty or failings
{bc}the back considered as an area of vulnerability

dt.t: the police officer's partner always watches his {wi}back{/wi}

dt: {bc}the part of a lower animal (such as a {d_link|quadruped|quadruped}) corresponding to the human back

dt.t: riding on the {wi}back{/wi} of an elephant
The title is on the book's {wi}back{/wi}.

dt: {bc}the side or surface opposite the front or face

dt.t: I only saw him from the {wi}back{/wi}.
wrote the number on the {wi}back{/wi} of an envelope

dt: {bc}something at or on the back for support
{bc}a position in some games (such as football or soccer) behind the front line of players
{bc}a swimming race in which swimmers use the {d_link|backstroke|backstroke}
{bc}the part of one's mind where thoughts and memories are stored to be drawn on

dt.t: One day, I was sitting in the tiny parlor {it}in back of{/it} the store …

et: Middle English, from Old English {it}bæc{/it}; akin to Old High German {it}bah{/it} back, Old Norse {it}bak{/it}
shortdef: the rear part of the human body especially from the neck to the end of the spine
the body considered as the wearer of clothes
capacity for labor, effort, or endurance
